case_name: Appellant Company v. Ramachandra Dhondo Datar

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 327 of 1959 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 327 of 1959. Appeal from the order dated June 28, 195

facts.text: Appeal from the order dated June 28, 1956, of the Bombay High Court at Nagpur in Misc. First Appeal No. 15 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the order dated June 28, 1956, of the Bombay High Court at Nagpur in Misc. First Appeal No. 15 of 1954. V. Viswanatha Sastri, Shankar Anand and A. G. Batnaparkhi, for the appellant.

facts.text: Ramachandra Dhondo Datar was employed by the appellant company in its publications branch.

anchor.surface_text: SHAH, J.-Ramachandra Dhondo Datar-hereinafter referred to as the respondent-was employed by the appellant companypany in its publications branch.

facts.text: By agreement dated March 23, 1943, the appellant company agreed to pay the respondent remuneration per annum equal to 3 1/2 % of the gross sales or Rs. 12,000 whichever was greater, as from April 1, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: By agreement dated March 23, 1943, the appellant companypany agreed to pay to the respondent as from April 1, 1943, remuneration per annum equal to 3 1/2 of the gross sales or Rs. 12,000 whichever was greater.

facts.text: The agreement was to remain in operation for ten years from April 1, 1943, and was renewable at the option of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement was to remain in operation for -ten years from April 1, 1943, in the first instance and was renewable at the option of the respondent for such period as he desired.

facts.text: By notice dated April 19, 1948, served on the respondent on April 22, 1948, the appellant company terminated the employment of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: By numberice dated April 19, 1948, served on the respondent on April 22, 1948, the appellant companypany terminated the employment of the respondent.

facts.text: The respondent filed a civil suit in the court of the Fifth Additional District Judge, Nagpur, for a decree for Rs. 1,30,000 being compensation for wrongful termination, arrears of salary and interest.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then filed a civil suit in the companyrt of the Fifth Additional District Judge, Nagpur, for a decree for Rs. 1,30,000 being the amount of companypensation for wrongful termination of employment, arrears of salary and interest.

facts.text: On July 17, 1953, the court passed a decree for Rs. 42,359 inclusive of Rs. 36,000 as compensation for termination and Rs. 6,000 as salary in lieu of six months notice and interest and costs.

anchor.surface_text: On July 17, 1953, the companyrt after giving credit for the amount received by the respondent passed a decree for Rs. 42,359  which was inclusive of Rs. 36,000 as companypensation for termination of employment and Rs. 6,000 as salary in lieu of six months numberice and interest  and companyts and interest on judgment.

facts.text: The respondent applied for execution of the decree and claimed Rs. 54,893-12-0 less Rs. 18,501-10-0 decreed against him in a cross suit filed by the appellant company.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then applied for execution of the decree and claimed Rs. 54,893-12-0 less Rs. 18,501-10-0 decreed against him in a cross suit filed by the appellant companypany.

facts.text: The Income Tax Officer, Nagpur, served a notice under s. 46 of the Indian Income Tax Act upon the respondent and gave intimation to the District Judge, Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer, Nagpur, served a numberice under s. 46 of the Indian Income Tax Act upon the respondent and also gave intimation to the District Judge, Nagpur, that the appellant companypany be permitted to deduct at source and to pay into the Government Treasury Rs. 15,95613-0 as income-tax, surcharge and super-tax due on the sum of Rs. 50,972-2-0 awarded to the respondent.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer intimated District Judge to permit appellant company to deduct Rs. 15,956-13-0 as income-tax, surcharge and super-tax on Rs. 50,972-2-0 awarded to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: that the appellant companypany be permitted to deduct at source and to pay into the Government Treasury Rs. 15,95613-0 as income-tax, surcharge and super-tax due on the sum of Rs. 50,972-2-0 awarded to the respondent.

facts.text: The appellant company applied to the executing court to declare that it was entitled to deduct the tax due on the amount.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany also applied that the executing Court do declare that the appellant companypany was entitled and in law bound to deduct the tax due on the amount.

facts.text: The District Judge directed the appellant company to pay Rs. 15,956-13-0 to Income Tax Department and the balance to court after filing receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge directed the appellant companypany to pay to the Income Tax Department Rs. 15,956-13-0 on account of income-tax and super-tax on the amount due to the respondent and directed it to pay the balance in companyrt after filing a receipt for payment of tax from the Income Tax department.

facts.text: In appeal to the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur, the order of District Judge was reversed and execution as claimed by respondent was directed.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur, the order passed by the District Judge was reversed and execution as claimed by the respondent was directed.

facts.text: It is undisputed that at the material time, no tax was assessed against the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: It is undisputed that at the, material time, numbertax was assessed against the respondent -the Income Tax Officer had accordingly numberauthority to issue a numberice under s. 46 5 .

facts.text: No provision was made in the decree for payment of income-tax due by the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: It may have been open to the appellant companypany in the suit to apply to the companyrt for making a provision in the decree for payment of income-tax due by the respondent, but numbersuch provision was made.

facts.text: The respondent filed suit for arrears of salary, compensation for wrongful termination and interest.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had filed a suit for a decree for arrears of salary, companypensation for wrongful termination of employment and interest.

facts.text: A substantial part of the decreed claim represented compensation for wrongful termination of employment.

anchor.surface_text: A substantial -part of the claim decreed represented companypensation fir wrongful termination of employment and it would be difficult to predicate of the claim sought to be enforced what part thereof if any represented salary due.

facts.text: Appellant company had a cross-decree for Rs. 18,501-10-0 against the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then applied for execution of the decree and claimed Rs. 54,893-12-0 less Rs. 18,501-10-0 decreed against him in a cross suit filed by the appellant companypany.

facts.text: Judgment was delivered on November 29, 1960 by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. November 29. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-

issues.text: whether as between the appellant companypany and the respondent the amount decreed is due as salary payment of which attracts the statutory liability imposed by s. 18

anchor.surface_text: The question to be determined is whether as between the appellant companypany and the respondent the amount decreed is due as salary payment of which attracts the statutory liability imposed by s. 18.

arguments.claim: Under s. 18(2) of the Income Tax Act, the appellant company was bound to deduct tax computed at the appropriate rate on the salary payable to the respondent as the amount due under the decree represented salary.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany contends that under s. 18 2  of the Income Tax Act, it was bound to deduct the tax computed at the appropriate rate on the salary payable to the respondent as the amount due under the decree represented salary. Section 18 sub-s.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rsuch provision was made. We are number companycerned to decide in this appeal whether in the hands of the respondent the amount due to him under the

arguments.court_reasoning: Decretal amount is judgment-debt, not salary; s.18 applies to salary payments, not decrees; execute per CPC tenor without tax provision.

arguments.claim: The Income Tax Officer had authority to issue notice under s.46(5) requiring deduction of tax arrears from the decreed amount.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany also applied that the executing Court do declare that the appellant companypany was entitled and in law bound to deduct the tax due on the amount.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: quisition and to pay the amount deducted to the credit of the Government. But this order can only be passed if income-tax has been assessed and has re

arguments.court_reasoning: No tax assessed against respondent at material time; s.46(5) requires prior assessment of unpaid tax.

arguments.claim: Executing court should permit deduction of tax and direct payment to Income Tax Department before paying balance to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge directed the appellant companypany to pay to the Income Tax Department Rs. 15,956-13-0 on account of income-tax and super-tax on the amount due to the respondent and directed it to pay the balance in companyrt after filing a receipt for payment of tax from the Income Tax department.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nt. The appellant companypany also applied that the executing Court do declare that the appellant companypany was e

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court reversed; Supreme Court upheld as no valid tax authority or provision in decree.

arguments.claim: Liability to deduct tax under s.18 arises only if amount due and payable as salary.

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 sub-s.  2  of the Income Tax Act in so far as it is material provides that any person paying any amount chargeable under the head salaries shall at the time of payment deduct income-tax and super-tax at the rate representing the average of the rates applicable to the estimated total income of the assessee under the head salary.

arguments.claim: Income Tax Officer had no authority to issue notice under s.46(5) as no tax was assessed.

anchor.surface_text: But this order can only be passed if income-tax has been assessed and has remained unpaid. It is undisputed that at the, material time, no tax was assessed against the respondent -the Income Tax Officer had accordingly no authority to issue a notice under s. 46 5 .

arguments.claim: Income Tax Officer cannot recover tax via garnishee proceeding on judgment-debt.

anchor.surface_text: Nor could the Income Tax Officer claim to recover tax due by a proceeding in the nature of a garnishee proceeding by applying to the civil companypanyrt to attach the Judgment-debt payable by the companypany.

arguments.claim: Decretal amount does not represent salary as between appellant and respondent; it is a judgment-debt.

anchor.surface_text: Undoubtedly, the employer is by s. 18 of the Act liable to deduct from the salary payable by him to his employee the amount of tax at the average rate appli- cable to the estimated total income but can it be said that as between the appellant companypany and the respondent the decretal amount represented salary?

arguments.claim: Decree must be executed according to its tenor, subject only to CPC-permitted deductions like cross-decree set-off; no tax deduction absent decree provision.

anchor.surface_text: The decree passed by the civil companypanyrt must be executed subject to the deductions and adjustments permissible under the Code of Civil Procedure. The judgment-debtor may, if he has a cross-decree for money, claim to set off the amount due thereunder.

arguments.claim: Westminster Bank Ltd. v. Riches supports deduction of tax from decreed interest as it is income, not damages.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant companypany strongly relied upon the decision of the House of Lords in Westminster Bank Ltd. v. Riches  1 . That was a case in which in an action brought by one R against the Westminster Bank trustee of the estate of one X-R was awarded a decree for pound 36,255 principal and pound 10,028 as interest.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a decree for pound 36,255 principal and pound 10,028 as interest. The Bank thereafter brought an action for a declaration that it had satisfied the ju

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished: here judgment-debt under CPC scheme; no separate action possible; amount not salary but judgment-debt without tax provision.

arguments.claim: Manickam Chettiar v. Income Tax Officer supports court's inherent power under CPC s.151 to direct payment of assessed tax from decree-holder's funds.

anchor.surface_text: The principle of the case in Manickam Chettiar v. Income Tax Officer, Madura  1 , on which reliance was also sought to be placed by the appellant companypany has numberapplication to this case. In Manickam Chettiars case  1 , in execution of a money decree certain properties belonging to a judgment- debtor were attached and sold and the sale proceeds were received by the companyrt.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: pondent was assessed to pay in respect of this amount till the date on which the -appellant companypany sought to satisfy the alleged tax liability of

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished: tax assessed there with recovery proceedings; here no assessment; different context of sale proceeds vs direct execution.

holdings.text: The Income Tax Officer had no authority to issue a notice under s. 46(5) as no tax had been assessed against the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: It is undisputed that at the, material time, numbertax was assessed against the respondent -the Income Tax Officer had accordingly numberauthority to issue a numberice under s. 46 5 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 46(5) permits requisition only if tax assessed and unpaid; undisputed no assessment at material time.

holdings.text: The Income Tax Officer could not recover tax due by garnishee proceedings to attach the judgment-debt.

anchor.surface_text: Nor could the Income Tax Officer claim to recover tax due by a proceeding in the nature of a garnishee proceeding by applying to the civil companypanyrt to attach the Judgment-debt payable by the companypany.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory basis for garnishee attachment of unassessed tax from judgment-debt; ITO application ignored.

holdings.text: As between the appellant company and respondent, the decretal amount did not represent salary.

anchor.surface_text: applicable to the estimated total income but can it be said that as between the appellant companypany and the respondent the decretal amount represented salary?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit claim for salary, compensation, interest merged into decree; becomes judgment-debt, not salary payable.

holdings.text: Amount decreed not due as salary attracting s.18 deduction liability.

anchor.surface_text: The question to be determined is whether as between the appellant companypany and the respondent the amount decreed is due as salary payment of which attracts the statutory liability imposed by s. 18.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decree for compensation (major part), arrears, notice pay, interest; assumes judgment-debt character; s.18 applies to salary payments, not decrees without tax provision.

holdings.text: Decree must be executed subject only to deductions and adjustments permissible under Code of Civil Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: The decree passed by the civil companypanyrt must be executed subject to the deductions and adjustments permissible under the Code of Civil Procedure. The judgment-debtor may, if he has a cross-decree for money, claim to set off the amount due thereunder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Execute per decree tenor; only CPC set-off (cross-decree), attachments allowed; no statutory provision for tax deduction absent decree direction.

holdings.text: Westminster Bank Ltd. v. Riches has no application.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, this case has numberapplication to the facts of the present case. In the case before us, there is a decree passed in favour of the respondent under the scheme of the Civil Procedure Code, that decree has to be executed as it stands, subject to such deductions or adjustments as are permissible under the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished: separate action possible there for interest tax deduction; here CPC bars separate action, direct execution of judgment-debt without tax provision.

holdings.text: Manickam Chettiar v. Income Tax Officer has no application.

anchor.surface_text: The principle of the case in Manickam Chettiar v. Income Tax Officer, Madura  1 , on which reliance was also sought to be placed by the appellant companypany has numberapplication to this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished: assessed tax with recovery from sale proceeds there; here no assessment, direct decree execution not sale proceeds.

holdings.text: No provision in Income Tax Act entitling debtor to deduct tax from judgment-debt on ground it originated from salary claim.

anchor.surface_text: under the scheme of the Civil Procedure Code, that decree has to be executed as it stands, subject to such deductions or adjustments as are permissible under the Code. There was numbertax liability which the respondent was assessed

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18 duty only on salary payments; post-decree, no statutory modification to CPC execution rules allowing tax deduction.

anchor.surface_text: Westminster Bank Ltd. v. Riches  1

precedents.cited_proposition: Judgment-debtor entitled to deduct income-tax on interest awarded under the judgment before satisfying the decree
precedents.cited_holding: 10,028 awarded as interest was liable to income-tax and deductible by the bank

anchor.surface_text: Manickam Chettiar v. Income Tax Officer, Madura  1

precedents.case_name: Manickam Chettiar v. Income Tax Officer, Madura
precedents.cited_proposition: Court has jurisdiction to direct payment of assessed income-tax due from decree-holder out of sale proceeds in court
precedents.cited_holding: Claim for income-tax entitled to priority and court can order payment to Income Tax Officer from sale proceeds

Code of Civil Procedure (Execution Provisions) support

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant company cannot deduct income-tax at source from the decretal amount as it is a judgment-debt, not salary; decree to be executed as it stands without tax deduction
directions: Decree to be executed according to its tenor subject only to deductions/adjustments permissible under Code of Civil Procedure
No deduction of income-tax by judgment-debtor (appellant company)
Defence to execution to be raised in execution proceedings only

anchor.surface_text: The decree passed by the civil companypanyrt must be executed subject to the deductions and adjustments permissible under the Code of Civil Procedure. The judgment-debtor may, if he has a cross-decree for money, claim to set off the amount due thereunder.

The decree passed by the civil companypanyrt must be executed subject to the deductions and adjustments permissible under the Code of Civil Procedure. The judgment-debtor may, if he has a cross-decree for money, claim to set off the amount due thereunder.

In our view, this case has numberapplication to the facts of the present case. In the case before us, there is a decree passed in favour of the respondent under the scheme of the Civil Procedure Code, that decree has to be executed as it stands, subject to such deductions or adjustments as are permissible under the Code.
The principle of the case in Manickam Chettiar v. Income Tax Officer, Madura  1 , on which reliance was also sought to be placed by the appellant companypany has numberapplication to this case.
